items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: In a Crowded City, Storage Rooms With Amenities
items.abstract: A new self-storage facility, with customer-friendly extras, has opened on Manhattan’s West Side, but analysts said the city remains underserved.

items.title: Cities Urge Public Pension Funds to Divest From Gun Makers
items.abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago urged the executives of two major banks to cease the financing of firearms companies. Other cities are making similar efforts.

items.title: Why American Giant Re-Designed Its Web Site
items.abstract: The metrics indicate the company made the right call. (Plus, the company has sold out all of its product.)

items.title: Patent Producers Clustered in Only a Few Cities
items.abstract: A new study by the Brookings Institution shows the high concentration of patented innovation in a relatively small number of metropolitan areas in America. Twenty metro areas — home to 34 percent of the population — generate 63 percent of the nation’s patents.

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: New York City to Get $176 Million From U.S. for Storm Protections
items.abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer said the city would be awarded federal funds for a proposed project to guard against another storm like Hurricane Sandy in Lower Manhattan.

items.title: Review: City Ballet Celebrates Balanchine and Heeds Mother Nature
items.abstract: The storm caused the company to cancel Saturday’s performance, an unfortunate interruption of momentum built in the first week of its winter season.

items.title: New York City’s Pension System in Danger of ‘Operational Failure,’ Report Says
items.abstract: The bureau managing the city’s retirement funds has not kept up with the times and lacks basic tools to identify risk, according to an independent report commissioned by the city comptroller’s office.

items.title: Greater Diversity Sought for New York City’s Community Boards
items.abstract: Councilman Ritchie Torres has a bill to collect and publicize information about the panels’ members. He hopes this will prompt the boards to better reflect the neighborhoods they serve.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: Students in Rural America Ask, ‘What Is a University Without a History Major?’
items.abstract: Financial and enrollment woes at schools like the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point have led to a scramble for fixes, such as dropping longstanding liberal arts degrees.

items.title: As If by Design, Their Connection Was Inevitable
items.abstract: William Ackman had been given two nudges by two friends to reach out to Neri Oxman. He found they were both right.

items.title: Are Electric Cars Only for the Rich? Sacramento Is Challenging That Notion
items.abstract: With funding from a surprising source, Volkswagen, California is making sure low-income communities have the chance to gain access to electric vehicles.

items.title: 19 Killed in New York City’s Deadliest Fire in Decades
items.abstract: Nine children were among those who died when a space heater malfunctioned in a Bronx apartment building, city officials said.

items.title: Eric Adams Ran on Making New York Safer. A Subway Killing Poses a Test.
items.abstract: The mayor, who made improving public safety a theme of his campaign, is dealing with the fallout from a high-profile death in Times Square.

items.title: House Hunting in Mexico City: Wood and Marble Mingle in a Stylish Triplex
items.abstract: Investors ‘are selling properties in Mexico City to reinvest in other countries,’ local agents say, boosting inventory and tamping down prices.

items.title: A Million More Trees for New York City: Leaders Want a Greener Canopy
items.abstract: The city’s five borough presidents are also urging the mayor to honor a pledge to spend 1 percent of the municipal budget on parks.

items.title: The Next Affordable City Is Already Too Expensive
items.abstract: In Spokane, Wash., home prices jumped 60 percent in the past two years. The increase is fueled by buyers fleeing the boom in cities like Austin. Who will have to flee next?
